fields: the cell is the {{c1::structural}} and {{c2::functional}} unit of the body
some cells secrete components of an {{c1::extraceullar matrix}}
Two types of organisms on earth:
which group of cells has a nucleus?
which group of cells has a cell wall?
which is larger, eukaryotes or prokaryotes?
basic DNA structure of prokaryotic cells
all cells originate from a {{c1::zygote}} which undergoes repeated cell divisions
prokaryotic cells undergo {{c1::fission}} reproduction and eukaryotic cells undergo {{c2::mitotic}} reproduction
undifferentiated cells whcih have not yet reached their mature form

cell differentiation brings about changes in...
1. {{c1::shape and size of cell}}
2. {{c1::membrane specializations}}
3. {{c1::organelles}}
4. {{c1::proteins expressed in the cell}}
5. {{c1::cellular function}}
everything inside the cell except the nucleus; cytosol, organelles, cytoskeleton and inclusions
selective barrier between inside and outside of the cell
4 main functions of the plasma membrane

1. regulates passage of materials in and out of cell
2. facilitates transport of molecules across the membrane
3. maintains ion concentrations inside the cell
4. carries out regulatory and recognition functions
the plasma membrane is {{c1::7.5 nm}} thick
attached to the inner or outer surface but not embedded
covers outer surface of plasma membrane; made of glycolipids and glycoproteins
involved in cell recognition and attachment to other cells or the extracellular matrix
passage of small molecules from an area of high concentration to an area of low cocentration; movement of small molecules inside or outside the cell membrane with concentration gradients
{{c1::lipophillic}} molecules pass through plasma membranes easily, while {{c1::water-soluable}} molecules pass through more slowly
proteins that form pores on the plasma membrane through which ions and small molecules can pass selectively are called {{c1::channels}}
{{c1::ion channels}} located on plasma membranes, can open or close in response to physiological stimuli
water passes through the plasma membrane through these channels
{{c1::carrier proteins}} bind small molecules and translocate them across the cell membrane via conformational changes
the process of bringing materials into the cell
the engulfing of bacteria, protozoa, dead cells or extracellular debris is called {{c1::phagocytosis}}
extracellular debris become surrounded by cell membrane and a {{c1::phagosome (phagocytic vesicle)}} forms, bringing the debris into the cell
{{c1::pinocytosis}} is the engulfing of {{c2::extracellular fluid}} and {{c2::dissolved materials}}
transcytosis is the movement of {{c1::pinocytic vesicles}} across a cell
in receptor-mediated endocytosis {{c1::ligands}} bind to surface receptors, the {{c1::receptor-ligand complex}} is engulfed in coated pits, eventually forming {{c2::clathrin}} coated vesicles
the release of materials from a cell
exocytosis is often triggered by a transient increase in cytosolic {{c1::Ca2+}}

1. vesicles containing material to be released move to the inner surface of the plasma membrane
2. the membrane of the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane
3. the vesicle opens to the outside of the cell to release its contents
4. the vesicle membrane is thus reinserted into the plasma membrane
cells must communicate with one another in order to regulate {{c1::development}}{{c1::growth}}{{c1::cell division}}{{c1::metabolic functions}}
cells communicate by sending each other {{c1::chemical}} and {{c1::electrical}} signals
the cells that receive specific signals are called
target cells have {{c1::specific receptors}} for the signaling molecules
type of signaling where hormones are carried in the bloodstream to target cells located throughout the body
chemical signals act on local cells close to the source of the signal
signals bind to receptors on the same cell type as the cell which released the signal
the signlaing molecule remains attached to the signaling cells, so that cell-cell interaction is required for the signal to bind to its receptor
neurotransmitter molecules are released at special cell junctions, called synapses; these chemical signals are then converted to electrical signals
{{c1::polypeptide hormones}} and {{c1::neurotransmitters}} are typically {{c2::hydrophilic}} signaling molecules

1. hydrophilic signal activates receptors on cell surfaces 
2. signal is transfuced by second messenger, starting a cascade of biochemical events leading to desired effect

1. bind to carrier proteins, which transport signaling molecules in the bloodstream
2. signaling molecules are released from the carrier protein and penetrate the plasma membrane 
3. signaling molecules bind to intracellular receptors
4. receptor-hormone complex moves into nucleus, binds to DNA and promotes or blocks gene transcription
{{c1::hydrophobic}} signaling molecules are involved in regulating gene transcription
ribosomes are {{c1::20 x 30 nm}} in size
ribosomes are made of a {{c1::small}} and a {{c1::large}} subunit
ribosomes {{c1::translate}} the genetic code by reading {{c2::mRNA code}}
ribosomes assemble {{c1::amino acids}} provided by {{c1::tRNA}} to produce {{c1::peptides}}
The ER is an interconnecting network of sacs and tubules formed by membranes that encloses
The RER is prominent in these cells
This organelle is formed by parallel stacks of flattened sac, covered on outer surface by ribosomes
{{c1::Odontoblasts}} have lots of {{c2::RER}} because they have a lot of {{c3::ribosomes}}
What are the roles of the RER?

Segregation of proteins not destined for cytosol

Glycosylation of glycoproteins

Assembly of multichain proteins

Posttranslational changes of newly formed peptides
This organelle lacks ribosomes, is continuous with RER, and is formed of interconnecting tubules
What are the roles of the SER?

Synthesis of membrane phospholipids

Steroid synthesis

Degradation of toxins and drugs in liver

Sequestering of Ca+ ions (sarcoplasmic reticulum)
Which face of the golgi is near the RER?
Which face of the golgi releases vesicles containing mature protein for utilization or secretion?
What are the roles of the golgi?

Modifies proteins by glycosylation, sulfation, phosphorylation, and proteolysis

Packages, concentrates and stores secretory products in vesicles
{{c1::Lysosomes}} are vesicles containing hydrolytic enzymes in acid pH
What are some examples of lysosomes?
Lysosomes are abundant in what cells?
Lysosomes are formed by proteins labeled with what?
Lysosomes fuse with what to form secondary lysosomes?
This remains after digestion, containing undigested materials
The inner membrane of mitochondria is folded in {{c1::cristae}}
The {{c2::inner membrane}} of mitochondria is impermeable to {{c1::ions}}
The number of {{c1::mitochondria and cristae}} are related to the energy demands of the cell
{{c1::Proteasomes}} are cylindrically shaped cytoplasmic protein complexes
What are the roles of proteasomes

Recognize ubiquitin labeled proteins

Degrade denatured or nonfunctional proteins

remove proteins not needed by the cell
What enzyme in peroxisomes breaks down hydrogen peroxide?
{{c1::Peroxisomes}} are involved in drug and FA metabolism
{{c1::Inclusions}} are nonmotile, non metabolic molecules in the body and are NOT organelles
Examples of {{c1::inclusions}} include fat droplets, glycogen granules, and lipofuscin granules
Pathogenic organisms including viruses can often be directly visualized by
The first screening step in arriving at a specific identification is
Organism's microscopic morphology and staining characteristics
What are some common techniques of direct visualization

Gram stain

Acid fast stain

India ink

Potassium hydroxide preparation
{{c1::Gram staining}} is the most common and useful staining procedure
Gram positive bacteria stain {{c1::purple}} and gram negative bacteria stain {{c2::pink/red}}
Microorganisms that lack cell walls, such as {{c1::mycoplasma}}, cannot be identified by the Gram stain.
What is the order of steps for gram staining?
Add crystal violet, iodine, acetone, then safrinin
Acid fast organisms like {{c1::Mycobacterium}} contain large amounts of {{c2::mycolic acids (fatty acids)}} within their cell walls
These acids resist staining by {{c1::Gram stain}} (due to lipid-rich cell walls) however they can be stained by {{c2::ZiehlNeelsen carbolfuchsin stain.}}
Acid-fast bacilli will be {{c1::pink/red}} after staining as they cannot be easily decolorized with acidified solvents
{{c1::India ink}} is useful in detecting {{c2::Crytococcus neoformans}} in CSF
In india inking, one drop of {{c1::centrifuged CSF}} is mixed with one drop of {{c2::India ink}} on a microscope slide beneath a glass cover slip
{{c1::Cryptococcus}} is identified by their {{c2::large, transparent capsules}} that displace the India ink particles
Treatment with {{c1::KOH}} {{c2::dissolves host cells and bacteria}}, sparing fungi
One drop of sputum or skin scraping in treated with {{c1::10 % KOH}}, and the specimen is examined for fungal forms.
{{c1::Fungi}} are recognized under the microscope by their {{c2::filamentous (hyphae) or round (oval)}} structures
